title-group.article-title: Gear fault detection under time-varying rotating speed via joint application of multiscale chirplet path pursuit and multiscale morphology analysis

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Mechanical Engineering, Xiamen University of Technology, Xiamen, China
2Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Ottawa, Ottawa, Canada
3State Key Laboratory of Advanced Design and Manufacturing for Vehicle Body, Hunan University, Changsha, China

author-notes.corresp: Ming Liang, Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Ottawa, 770 King Edward Avenue, Ottawa, ON K1N6N5, Canada Email: liang@eng.uottawa.ca

abstract.p: This article reports a new method for gear fault detection under time-varying rotating speed. This method is based on the chirplet path pursuit and multiscale morphology analysis. The instantaneous rotating speed is extracted from the gear vibration signal using the multiscale chirplet path pursuit algorithm. According to the extracted rotation speed, the gear vibration signal is resampled at constant angle increment and as such the nonstationary signal is converted into a stationary signal. The fault-induced impulsive features can then be extracted from the resampled signal via the multiscale morphology analysis, followed by the spectrum analysis to reveal the fault characteristic frequency. Because of the low correlations between the noise and chirplet functions, the rotational speed can be extracted effectively even when the signal-to-noise ratio of the vibration signal is relatively low. In addition, the noise effect can be further suppressed by averaging the results of morphology analyses of all the scales. Therefore, the proposed approach has a good antinoise ability and is suitable for gear fault detection under time-varying rotational speed. The performance of the method has been validated by both simulation and experimental data.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: When a gear has a local fault, the modulation of the meshing frequency, as a result of faulty teeth, generates sidebands, that is, the frequency components equally spaced around a center frequency. In other words, the meshing frequency and its harmonics are usually modulated by the frequency of the shaft rotation speed and its harmonics in gear vibration spectra.1 The increase in the number and the amplitude of such sidebands often indicates faulty conditions.2 Therefore, the demodulation analysis is an effective tool for fault diagnosis. Hilbert transform (HT) and Teager energy operator (TEO) have shown to be useful for demodulation.3–6 The multiscale morphology (MSM) analysis has also been proposed to detect bearing faults. In Ref. 7, Zhang et al. have verified that the MSM analysis is an effective and robust tool to extract impulsive signal components of the vibration signal, and the fault characteristic frequencies can be clearly identified on the spectrum generated by applying the MSM analysis. Therefore, the MSM in conjunction with the fast Fourier transform (FFT) has a good demodulation effect and hence could be considered as a demodulation method. Compared to traditional methods such as HT and TEO, the MSM-based demodulation has some important advantages such as the simplicity in computations as it requires only additions and subtractions, better performance in suppressing noise, and no spectrum leakage. However, all these demodulation approaches are based on the Fourier analysis and hence cannot be directly applied to demodulating nonstationary vibration signals.

For rotating machinery, the speedup and speeddown processes contain valuable information that reflects certain fault symptoms but cannot be found in the stationary process.8 In fact, gears are often tested at automatically controlled variable load and speed on test rigs by gear manufacturers. Such a practice helps expose the gear faults and reduce testing time and costs. This indicates that there is no steady speed time interval during the tests,9 which has inspired the researchers to detect faults of rotating machinery with time-varying rotating speed.8–14 Due to the nonstationarity of the vibration signals, when the conventional FFT-based methods are used, the smearing problem generally arises in practical implementation particularly at variable rotational speed. This often leads to misdiagnosis. With the equal-angle-interval resampling processing,15 the nonstationary signal in time domain is converted into a stationary signal in the angular domain. Shaft speed estimation is very important in the resampling process.15,16 Improper resampling may cause misleading results.

In this article, the multiscale chirplet path pursuit (MSCPP) algorithm17,18 is adopted to estimate instantaneous shaft speed, the essential information for fault detection under variable speed. Our simulation results show that the rotating speed can be estimated accurately by the MSCPP algorithm from the vibration signal, even if the vibration signal is buried in noise. In Ref. 19, the MSCPP algorithm together with the sparse signal decomposition theory was applied to gear fault diagnosis under variable shaft rotational speed. However, the MSCPP algorithm has to be applied repeatedly in Ref. 19. Because the MSCPP algorithm requires a global search of all the parameters, such an approach is very burdensome computationally. This obviously undermines its applications to online fault detection, particularly to condition monitoring for time-varying speed operations, the very purpose of this type of research. As such, we further propose a joint MSCPP and MSM approach to variable-speed gear fault diagnosis via accurate speed estimation (by the MSCPP) and robust fault impulse feature extraction (by the MSM). Unlike in Ref. 19, the MSCPP algorithm in our proposed approach is used only once for speed estimation. Therefore, this new approach is much more efficient than the method reported in Ref. 19 and is thus more suited to fault detection under time-varying conditions. More specific reasons for us to adopt the combined approach are as follows: (a) the multiscale method makes the chirplet path pursuit more flexible—it can use shorter chirplet templates whenever the instantaneous frequency exhibits a complicated structure and switch to longer chirplet templates if the instantaneous frequency has a simpler structure; (b) the MSCPP algorithm does not require any priori information about the phase and amplitude; (c) for the MSM analysis, the structuring elements can be directly determined based on the peak values of the analytic signal; and (d) both MSCPP and MSM have very good antinoise properties. Therefore, the shaft speed can be estimated accurately and the fault impulsive features can be extracted effectively even if the signal-to-noise ratio of the original gear vibration signal is relatively low. Our simulation and experimental results have shown that the proposed approach performs reasonably well in detecting gear faults and is less susceptible to noise.

In a rotating mechanical system, the damage of a gear may generate impacts. The impact signals may contain more information about the fault. sec.title: MSCPP algorithm
sec.p: The MSCPP algorithm was first proposed to detect nonstationary signal from very noisy data by Candès et al.17 In the following, we provide a brief overview of the MSCPP algorithm. We will then apply and extend the MSCPP algorithm for detecting the signal component with the largest energy in the multicomponent vibration signal and estimating its instantaneous frequency.

Assuming that the time span of the analytic data is
[ 0 , T ]
and the sampling interval is
Δ t
, the time span can also be expressed as
[ 0 , N ] × Δ t
, where
N
is the number of sampling points. Let
j

The next step of MSCPP is to use the best path algorithm17 to form a matching signal

If we extend the MSCPP algorithm to the multicomponent vibration signals, such as machinery vibration signals, the best path algorithm can guarantee that during the entire analysis time period the total energy of the signal component formed by connecting chirplets is the maximum. In other words, the signal component formed in such a way is the signal component with the largest energy of the original vibration signal. By adjoining the piecewise linear frequencies of the chirplets, the instantaneous frequency of the signal component with the largest energy of the original vibration signal can be estimated.

sec.title: Combined MSCPP and MSM approach to gear fault diagnosis under variable shaft speed
sec.p: In this section, a new demodulation method is proposed for fault diagnosis of gears running at time-varying speed. In general, for the gear vibration signals, the meshing frequency component has the largest energy among all the signal components. As such, the meshing frequency can be estimated using the MSCPP algorithm. Once this is done, the gear shaft speed can be obtained by dividing the gear meshing frequency by the number of gear teeth. According to the extracted rotation speed, the gear vibration signal is resampled at constant angle increments, which converts the nonstationary signal in time domain into stationary signal in angular domain. It is therefore possible to apply the MSM analysis to detecting the faults of gears operating at varying speed.

Based on the above discussions, the fault diagnosis procedure can be summarized as follows (
x ( t )
= the original gear vibration signal):

list-item.p: Estimate shaft speed by chaining the piecewise linear frequencies of the selected chirplets using the MSCPP algorithm.
Resample the gear vibration signal at constant angle increment according to the estimated rotation speed. The resampling process can be carried out according to Ref. 15.

Calculate all the structuring elements for the MSM analysis using the adaptive search algorithm based on the information of local peaks of the resampled signal
x ′ ( t )
.

Compute
DIF
α
i
( x ′ )
using equation (13) for each structuring element
α
i
, where
i = 1 , 2 , … , L
,
L
is the number of scales, and then average the results to obtain the impulsiveness signature, that is
Perform the spectrum analysis and identify gear fault, if any, from the modulation frequency shown on the frequency spectrum.

sec.p: It should be noted that both the MSCPP and MSM methods are relatively immune to noise. In particular, the correlations between the noise and the chirplet functions are very low, and hence, the MSCPP algorithm is robust to noisy signals. By averaging the results of each scale morphology analysis, the MSM analysis will further smoothen out the noise.

sec.title: Simulation studies
sec.p: To validate the proposed method, an amplitude modulation (AM) signal is constructed as follows to imitate the gear vibration signal

where
σ ( t )
is the Gaussian white noise, which is added by MATLAB function awgn.m, and the signal-to-noise ratio is −9 dB. From equation (22), we can see that the meshing frequency is modulated by the shaft rotational frequency. The shaft rotational frequency is expressed as
f
s
= 6 ( t − 1
)
2
+ 2 ( t − 1 ) + 30
. The number of teeth is 10. Suppose the sampling frequency is 2000 Hz, and the number of samples is 2048. Figures 1 and 2 show the time-domain waveform of the simulated signal and the simulated signal with noise, respectively. The frequency domain representation of the noisy signal is plotted in Figure 3, and the time–frequency (TF) spectrogram based on the Wigner–Ville distribution (WVD) is shown in Figure 4. From Figures 3 and 4, we can see that the AM signal is almost completely submerged in noise, and it is unlikely to acquire any AM information from these results. Consequently, it is very difficult to use the existing frequency estimation methods to extract the shaft speed. For example, it is almost impossible to obtain the shaft speed by extracting the ridges of the TF landscape20 or searching the peak of the TF analysis.15

caption.p: Waveform of the simulated signal.
Waveform of the simulated signal with the added noise.
Frequency spectrum of the noisy simulation signal.
TF spectrogram of the noisy simulation signal based on the WVD.
TF: time–frequency; WVD: Wigner–Ville distribution.

sec.p: The search ranges of the frequency slope and offset coefficients are set as between −100 and 100 Hz and between 0 and 1000 Hz, respectively, and the search resolution for both the frequency slope and offset are set as 1 Hz. Figure 5 shows that the meshing frequency can be obtained by adjoining the piecewise linear frequency of the chirplets. Therefore, the shaft speed can be obtained by dividing the estimated meshing frequency by the number of teeth. Then, the nonstationary simulated signal can be converted into a stationary signal in angular domain with the equal-angle-interval resampling technique.15

caption.p: Instantaneous meshing frequency (the dotted line denotes the true instantaneous meshing frequency, and the solid line segments denote the estimated instantaneous meshing frequency).

sec.p: The resampled signal is shown in Figure 6. However, the AM still cannot be observed in this figure due to the high level of noise. We then demodulate the resampled signal via the MSM analysis and plot the result in Figure 7. From Figure 7, we can conclude that the meshing frequency was modulated by the shaft rotational frequency, which is in agreement with equation (22).

caption.p: Resampled signal for the noisy simulation signal.
Demodulation result of the resampled signal based on the MSM analysis.
MSM: multiscale morphology.

sec.p: For comparison, the demodulation results based on HT and TEO are displayed in Figures 8 and 9, respectively. Comparing Figure 7 with Figures 8 and 9 suggests that the MSM analysis is effective for demodulation.

caption.p: Demodulation result of the resampled signal based on the Hilbert transform.
Demodulation result of the resampled signal based on TEO.
TEO: Teager energy operator.

sec.p: To further examine the performance of the presented method, we consider another simulated signal blended with noise n(t) as follows

The signal-to-noise ratio of the signal mixture is −6. Suppose the sampling frequency is 1000 Hz, and the data length is 1024 samples. From equation (23), we know that the simulated rotating speed can be modeled as
f
′
s
= 6
t
2
+ 6 t + 30
, and the simulated gear has 10 teeth. The time-domain waveform and the frequency spectrogram of the simulated signal are shown in Figures 10 and 11, respectively. From the two figures, the modulation features cannot be directly obtained.

caption.p:
Simulated signal
x
.

Spectrum of the simulated signal
x
.

sec.p: With the MSCPP algorithm, the instantaneous meshing frequency can be estimated and the result is represented by the solid line segments in Figure 12, which are a good approximation of the actual instantaneous meshing frequency.

caption.p:
Instantaneous meshing frequency of the simulation signal
x
(the dotted line denotes actual instantaneous meshing frequency, and the solid line denotes the estimated instantaneous meshing frequency).

sec.p: Following the same procedure as used for the previous simulated signal, the instantaneous shaft speed can be obtained and the nonstationary simulated signal can be converted into a stationary signal. Figure 13 shows the waveform of the resampled signal that reveals no modulation information, possibly again caused by noise.

caption.p:
Resampled signal of the simulation signal
x
.

sec.p: For further comparison, we plot the demodulation results of the resampled signal obtained by the MSM, HT, and TEO methods in Figures 14 to 16, respectively. From Figure 14, we can clearly see a spectral peak located at the order of 1.035, indicating that the meshing frequency is modulated by the shaft rotational frequency. This is in consistent with equation (23). However, such a spectral peak cannot be observed in both Figures 15 and 16, suggesting that the HT and TEO methods are less effective in demodulating the resampled signal as compared with the proposed approach.

caption.p: Demodulation result of the resampled signal obtained by MSM.
MSM: multiscale morphology.
Demodulation result of the resampled signal obtained by HT.
HT: Hilbert transform.
Demodulation result of the resampled signal obtained by TEO.
TEO: Teager energy operator.

sec.title: Experimental validation
sec.p: To validate the proposed method, we applied it to detect two types of gear faults, that is, broken tooth and tooth crack from gear vibration signals collected from a gearbox (Figure 17). The details are presented in the following.

caption.p: Test rig.

sec.title: Case 1: detection of broken gear tooth
sec.p: As shown in Figure 17, there is a broken tooth on the input gear. The numbers of teeth of the gears in the input shaft and the output shaft are 55 and 75, respectively. Therefore, the meshing frequency is 55 times of the rotational frequency of the input shaft. The acceleration signal is sampled under time-varying rotation speed as shown in Figure 18, and the shaft speed is measured by a tachometer. The sampling rate is 4096 Hz and the sampling time is 2 s.

caption.p: Time-varying rotation speed.

sec.p: The raw signal and its frequency spectrum are plotted in Figure 19 and 20, respectively. Many impulses resulted from the broken tooth can be observed in Figure 19. However, the time intervals between adjacent impulses are not equal. Such unequally spaced impulses are due to the time variations in the shaft rotation speed. It is impossible to distinguish sidebands or to determine the type and location of the gearbox fault based on the frequency spectrum as shown in Figure 20.

caption.p: Waveform of the gear vibration signal (Case 1).
Frequency spectrum of the gear vibration signal (Case 1).

sec.p: According to the Nyquist sampling theorem, the maximum analysis frequency should be no more than half of the sampling rate. The search range of frequency offset coefficient is therefore set as between 0 and 2048 Hz and that of the slope coefficient between −100 and 100 Hz. The search step for both coefficients is selected as 1 Hz. With the MSCPP method, the instantaneous meshing frequency can be estimated by connecting the piecewise linear frequency of the chirplets. The estimated instantaneous meshing frequency is displayed in Figure 21. It shows that the estimated meshing frequency is very close to the meshing frequency calculated based on the shaft speed measured by the tachometer. This suggests that the MSCPP method can indeed provide reasonably accurate result of instantaneous meshing frequency.

caption.p: Meshing frequency of Case 1 (the dotted line shows the meshing frequency obtained based on the shaft speed measured by a tachometer, and the solid line shows the estimated meshing frequency based on the MSCPP method).
MSCPP: multiscale chirplet path pursuit.

sec.p: According to the estimated rotational speed, the nonstationary gear vibration signal is resampled at constant angle increments to convert it into stationary signal. Then the MSM analysis is carried out on the resampled signal to extract the impulse features caused by the gear fault. The extracted impulses can be clearly seen in Figure 22. The frequency representation of the impulsive signal is plotted in Figure 23. The most dominant peak is observed at about two times of the input shaft frequency, that is, the meshing frequency is modulated by the second-order rotational frequency, a clear sign of a faulty tooth on the input gear.

caption.p: Impulse feature extracted by the proposed method (Case 1).
Demodulation result of the gear vibration signal using the proposed method (Case 1).

sec.title: Case 2: detection of gear tooth crack
sec.p: In this case, the same test rig shown in Figure 17 is used. The faulty gear in the input shaft is replaced with a normal gear, and the normal gear in the output shaft is changed to a gear with a fine crack at the root of one tooth as shown in Figure 24. The numbers of teeth of the normal gear in the input shaft and the crack gear in the output shaft are still 55 and 75, respectively. Consequently, the meshing frequency is 75 times of the rotational frequency of the output shaft.

caption.p: The output gear with a root crack.

sec.p: The vibration data are acquired at a sampling frequency of 4096 Hz. A portion of the data is presented in Figure 25. It is obviously difficult to detect the fault and pinpoint its location directly from the raw signal. The proposed method is then applied to the collected data with the search range of frequency offset coefficient also set as between 0 and 2048 Hz, and that of the slope coefficient specified as between −100 and 100 Hz. The search step for both coefficients is 1 Hz. The instantaneous meshing frequency is estimated by linking the piecewise linear frequency of the chirplets that is plotted in Figure 26. Thus, the gear time-varying shaft speed can be obtained by dividing the estimated gear instantaneous meshing frequency by the number of gear teeth, 75 in this case. With the obtained time-varying shaft speed, the gear vibration signal is resampled at constant angular increments. This converts the nonstationary signal in the time domain into stationary signal in the angular domain. Then, the impulse features caused by the gear fault can be extracted from the resampled signal via the MSM analysis. The frequency representation of the extracted impulsive signal is shown in Figure 27, which reveals a dominant peak at about two times of the output shaft frequency. Therefore, the meshing frequency is also modulated by the second-order rotational frequency. This indicates a faulty tooth on the output gear.

caption.p: Waveform of the gear vibration signal (Case 2).
The estimated instantaneous meshing frequency by the MSCPP method (Case 2).
MSCPP: multiscale chirplet path pursuit.
Demodulation result of the gear vibration signal using the proposed method (Case 2).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The chirplet path pursuit algorithm and the MSM analysis have been jointly applied to detect gear faults under variable shaft speed. With the proposed method, the modulation sideband can be extracted accurately from the time-varying gear vibration signal by the proposed method, which provides critical information for fault diagnosis. The main advantages of the proposed method include the following: (a) it is adaptive in that it does not require precise information about the phase and amplitude of the vibration signals and thus is suited for real applications, and (b) it is relatively robust to noise due to the low correlations between the noise and chirplet functions, as well as the multiscale averaging. Our simulation and experimental results have shown that the proposed method can effectively enforce order tracking and extract the fault features.

ack.p: The authors would like to thank the two reviewers for their valuable suggestions and comments that have helped improve this article.
